Award.AwardTitle: EarthCube RCN: Collaborative Research: Research Coordination Network for High-Performance Distributed Computing in the Polar Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the major current challenges with polar cyberinfrastructure is managing and fully exploiting the
volume of high-resolution commercial imagery now being collected over the polar regions. This data can be used to understand the changes in polar regions due to climate change and other processes. The potential of global socio-economic costs of these impacts make it an urgent priority to better understand polar systems. Understanding the mechanisms that underlie polar climate change and the links between polar and global climate systems requires a combination of field data, high-resolution observations from satellites, airborne imagery, and computer model outputs. Computational approaches have the potential to support faster and more fine-grained integration and analysis of these and other data types, thus increasing the efficiency of analyzing and understanding the complex processes. This project will support advances in computing tools and techniques that will enable the Polar Sciences Community to address significant challenges, both in the short and long-term.

The impact of this project will be in the improvements in the ability to utilize advanced cyberinfrastructure and high-performance distributed computing to fundamentally alter the scale, sophistication and scope of polar science problems that will be addressed. This project will not implement those changes but will identify and lay the groundwork for such impact across the Polar Sciences. The Project personnel will identify primary barriers to the uptake of high-performance and distributed computing and will help alleviate them through a combination of community based solutions and training. The project will also produce a roadmap detailing a credible and effective way to meet the long-term computing challenges faced by the Polar Science community and possible plans to effectively address them. This project will establish mechanisms for community engagement which include, gathering technical requirements for polar cyberinfrastructure and supporting and training early career scientists and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The promise of computational methods and tools that use  advanced, scalablecyberinfrastructure, leading to  better and faster discoveries is immense.However, there are many challenges in the uptake of advancedcyberinfrastructure in polar science. This Polar High-Performance andDistributed Computing project identified and articulated several of theunderlying factors that prevent greater uptake and penetration of advancedcomputing in Polar Science, and thus aimed to transform the way science isbeing done by polar community at large.


Building upon the core findings of the 2014 NSF­ Workshop on Polar Sciencesand High-Performance and Distributed Computing, where the need for access toand efficient utilization of advanced cyberinfrastructure was raised as acritical end­-user need and an outcome recommendation, this PolarHigh-Performance and Distributed Computing research coordination network hadtwo primary outcomes


The first was an extensive analysis of HPDC cyberinfrastructurerequirements of the Polar Sciences, viewing the Polar Sciences­t to ­HPDCconnection through the lens of current and future challenges. The project laidthe groundwork to make difficult polar science problems routine. The outcomesare captured and described in detail in the polar cyberinfrastructurecommunity white paper (CWP) available at: 10.5281/zenodo.3372882


The second outcome was to focus the relevant polar science andcyberinfrastructure communities on one dominant Polar science challenge ­ inHigh-Performance and Distributed Computing, viz., high resolution remotesensing image processing ­ which led to gaining a better understanding of thefundamental problems of enabled polar science and exploration.
The second outcome facilitated information exchange between these communitiesand ultimately help develop the infrastructure that would allow forhigh-­throughput, visual computing­ enabled classification of imagery at thecontinent scale. It also led to significant training efforts and activityspread over several events, communities, and pedagogical styles.

 

This project led to both significant bi­directional knowledge and skillstransfer and deep exploration of the space of potential solutions.
